ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Comprehensive knowledge of photovoltaic physics, operating principles, main design considerations, as well as overview of current developments and challenges in the field. Carrier statics and dynamics in semiconductor junctions, effects of light and light absorption, recombination. Practice with characterizing and testing solar panels.

Knowledge about how solar cells work approached from a few different angles, including charge transport dynamics, fermi levels, measures of efficiency/effectiveness of different materials and types of solars, and then in the final project we learned about one specific type of solar cell.

I gained a solid understanding of the semiconductor physics of solar cells. The homework in this class required understanding of many concepts in applied physics and helped me improve my comprehension in this area.
Great survey of topics from the solid state behind p-n junctions, to engineering an actual solar cell
Awesome class, definitely take it if you want to know how solar cells actually work, and you learn A TON about everything involved with them.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The course is very well organized. Problem sets and exams are very helpful in reinforcing course content and are in good agreement with lectures. Material is presented in an easy-to-understand sequence. The solar panel testing lab was incredibly helpful for understanding basic behavior of solar cells and how to test their functioning, and the final research presentation on a topic of the students choice was also a great way to dive deeper into individual interests. Given that class meeting times were always shorter than scheduled, the course would benefit tremendously from covering more topics, particularly semiconductor growth and manufacturing techniques, cell packaging, and module assembly, as all these topics are incredibly pertinent to anyone working in or studying the field, but are currently missing from the course altogether.

Overall, this is a great course! The lectures were always engaging and very clear (and Prof. Xia would stop to clarify anything that was unclear), and the psets were interesting and had us apply a wide range of applicable skills. 

One way the course could be improved is through increased clarity for some of the homework assignments (for example, for the outline in HW 9 what were different components we should have made sure to include?). Additionally, perhaps the lab could be done a bit earlier in the semester so that there are not 3 major assignments all due around the same time at the end. These are minor though in comparison to the overall great experience of the class!

Strengths: The teaching was great and the TA was phenomenal. Good variety of assignments and a fair workload. 

Weaknesses: Homework questions were often vague, so more specificity would be helpful.

Strengths: well organized, material was clearly taught, assignments were representative of material

Weaknesses: the excel psets werent adding much to the whole experience of the learning and the course could definitely do without

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would absolutely recommend this course to anyone interested in photovoltaics, both working in the solar industry or researching novel photovoltaic approaches. It is a quite comprehensive primer that effectively prepares a student for entry into the field.
Absolutely, it was my favorite class this semester! I learned so much, and the content was so interesting! Both prof Xia and the TA Manuel were always willing to help and answer any questions we had.

Yes, I felt that this class was a great upper level elective for applied physics and EE majors. It built on concepts from previous classes and dove into a super interesting and relevant application of that knowledge. I feel like I really came away with a better understanding of solar cells and could apply this knowledge in other contexts.
Yes! Phenomenally taught, great survey of topics
If you're interested in solar energy and have a science background, go for it.
